course_name: Early to High Renaissance Art & Architecture
course_description: Major monuments, buildings and art works of the period from several critical perspectives including the humanist influence on the arts in Florence and Rome, the issue of patronage and the question of the artist's cultural status.
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as MARS 2P92 and VISA 2P92

course_description: Overview of the intellectual, political and social forces that have shaped modern-day Italy. Focus on historical periods and how these are reflected in art, literature, architecture and society. Selected texts and multi-media material.
prerequisites: Notes: Open to majors and minors. Click on course name to see restriction for list. This course consists of 2hrs in-person and 1hr onl ine-asynchronous. given in English. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: History of the Early Roman Empire
course_description: History of Rome from the Battle of Actium to the death of Marcus Aurelius (180 CE) emphasizing social and political developments.

course_name: Art&Architecture of Roman Republic & Early Em
course_description: Art and architecture of the cultures of the Italian peninsula, in the first millennium BC, within the framework of cultural change and external influences.
prerequisites: Notes: one credit from CLAS or VISA 1Q98 and 1Q99 recommended. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: Art & Architecture of the Roman Empire
course_description: Roman art and architecture from Augustus to Late Antiquity. Christian art and architecture and the influence of Roman aesthetics on the Renaissance and beyond.
prerequisites: Notes: one credit from CLAS or VISA 1Q98 and 1Q99 recommended. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Dante's Divine Comedy and the world it created and reflected focusing on the Inferno. References to relevant visual arts (illustrations and adaptations of the Divine Comedy by such artists as Doré, Rodin and the Pre-Raphaelites).
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as MARS 3P93
